channel.title: BBC News | News Front Page | World Edition
channel.description: Visit BBC News for up-to-the-minute news, breaking news, video, audio and feature stories. BBC News provides trusted World and UK news as well as local and regional perspectives. Also entertainment, business, science, technology and health news.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse

item.title: Olmert urges Palestinian action
item.description: Israel's prime minister uses a speech to the US Congress to urge the Palestinians to be a willing peace partner.

item.title: Turkey airport fire under control
item.description: A fire that engulfed the cargo area of Istanbul international airport is under control, Turkish officials say.

item.title: US shares up while market jitters
item.description: US shares finish ahead while European markets slide further amid concerns about inflationary pressures.

item.title: US immigration bill clears hurdle
item.description: The US Senate clears the way for controversial immigration reform but tough talks lie ahead before it becomes law.

item.title: Russia plans wide military reform
item.description: Russia's defence minister announces widespread reform of the military including the axing of 300 senior posts.

item.title: Iran nuclear offer bid 'progress'
item.description: Major world powers report "good progress" progress in talks on incentives for Iran to end its nuclear programme.

item.title: Elusive Uganda rebel in war plea
item.description: The elusive head of Uganda's Lord's Resistance Army calls for an end to 20 years of war in a DVD appearance.

item.title: Aziz testifies for Saddam defence
item.description: Iraqi former Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz appears as a defence witness in Saddam Hussein's trial.

item.title: Stones postpone Europe concerts
item.description: The Rolling Stones postpone 15 European concerts following guitarist Keith Richards's brain surgery.

item.title: Tennis: Roddick on injury list
item.description: Andy Roddick joins Lleyton Hewitt on the list of casualties ahead of the French Open.

item.title: Football: Vieira robbery probed
item.description: Gas was pumped into Patrick Vieira's house before intruders stole jewellery and fled in his Mercedes.

item.title: Gun battle breaks Somalia truce
item.description: Fighting between warlords and Islamic militia resumes in the Somali capital, Mogadishu, despite a recent truce.

item.title: Aristocrat denies Kenyan murder
item.description: A UK aristocrat denies killing a man on his farm in Kenya, the second time in a year he has faced such a charge.

item.title: GM to top up drivers' fuel bills
item.description: Problem-hit General Motors offers petrol price subsidies for people driving its vehicles in California and Florida.

item.title: Mexico president in US for talks
item.description: Mexico wants to be part of the solution in the immigration debate, says the Mexican leader on a US visit.

item.title: Alarm at human bird flu cluster
item.description: The WHO says it is very worried about a cluster of recent human deaths from bird flu in Indonesia.

item.title: Relief force answers E Timor call
item.description: International troops head to East Timor to try to quell unrest blamed on 600 soldiers sacked in April.

item.title: EU bid to end 'asylum-shopping'
item.description: EU officials fail to agree on a list of countries from where asylum applications will be presumed to be unfounded.

item.title: Jail for scandal-hit Skandia boss
item.description: A former chief executive at Swedish insurance firm Skandia is jailed for handing out millions of pounds in bonuses without permission.

item.title: Iraqi PM optimistic over security
item.description: Iraq's PM says his forces will be ready to take over all security responsibilities in the country within 18 months.

item.title: Four die in Israeli W Bank raid
item.description: Four Palestinians are killed in Ramallah by Israeli troops during an incursion to arrest Palestinian militants.

item.title: Afghan clash 'kills 60 Taleban'
item.description: Sixty Taleban fighters and five Afghan security personnel die in a clash in the south, an Afghan general says.

item.title: Grenade attack amid Kashmir talks
item.description: Four people are injured in an attack in Kashmir as the Indian PM begins talks with officials and politicians.

item.title: Reid 'furious' over wrong figures
item.description: John Reid is understood to be furious after he had to admit giving MPs the wrong figures on foreign prisoners.

item.title: Nike and Apple join up for runs
item.description: Nike and Apple, two of the world's best-known brands, join forces and make equipment for runners.

item.title: UN report flags up India drug use
item.description: A UN report highlights concern over rising drug abuse and its impact on the spread of HIV in north-eastern India.

item.title: Planet shine 'to aid life search'
item.description: Telescope technologies are being developed that will probe the very faint light from distant planets for tell-tale signs of life.

item.title: Social sites wrestle for top spot
item.description: Bebo and MySpace are fighting for dominance of the online social networking scene, research shows.

item.title: Sir Elton vampire musical closes
item.description: Sir Elton John's vampire musical Lestat is to close on New York's Broadway after just 39 shows.
